bboxes.raw_text:
CHICAGO "A former president
of the American Cancer Society
says lung cancer will cause 40
per cent of all deaths in the
United States 20 years hence
unless something is done to pre-
vent it."


DIR. Alton Ochsner of New Or
leans, asserting that "all but
one kind of cancer are produced
by smoking" said mortality sta
tistics give no support to spec
ulation that smog IS lung can
Ger agent in some regions.

Mr.. and Mrs. Bobby Ray De-
Witt, 8l6 W. Mckinley. filed
suitroveEnthee deathsof, their son.
Bobby Lynn. The 100000 suit.
filed by Attorney Jay Dushoff.
alleges Peggy Lorraine Bell, 81,
of 1901 w. Pima. was negligent
in her operation of the car that
struck their 7 year old son.


The fatality happened on Jan.
20 on. Seventh Avenue near Tay-
lor. Miss Bell was not cited by
police in the accident.


The suit alleges she was speed
ing, did not keep proper look
out and did not have her vehicle
under control.

Planned Parenthood Associa-
tion will open its third clinic at
the First Congregational Church,
9th and Myrtle. Tempe, April 6.


An open house will be held
from to E pm


The clinic offers birth control
advice and supplies, education
for marriage, infertility counsel
ing and cancer detection tests.
They are stated by registered
OBJ. : Gym and qualified social
workers. The patients will be
admitted on the first and third
Monday nights of the month. APP
pointments may be made by call
ing AL 2-59ll.


Other planned parenthood elm
les are located in the Memorial
Hospital at Phoenix and G lendale.

About 67.8 per cent of Ameri-
can husbands take maps on the liv-
ing room sofa after dinner, &C
cording to a survey by a furni-
ture manufacturer.


The average nap is half an
hour. But 81 per cent sleep for
an hour or more and about 10
per cent are likely to sleep for
the entire evening on the sofa.


The concern made the survey
to find out how its sofas were
being used.

NEW YORK = Nal Whitfield,
Olympic gold medal winner in
1913 and 1852 in the 800 meter
races. urged all American Ne
gro athletes eligible for the Tok-
20 Olympics to boycott the games
if full rights are not granted
by that time.


In an Ebony magazine article
Whitfield said probably Is per
cent of the U S. track team would
be Negroes.


II think every athlete and every
coach should be dedicated to the
real purpose of going abroad to
represent a free country. We
are not representing afree coun-
try when we do not stand for
equal rights" he wrote.


Whitfield won the Sullivan A
ward of the AAU in 1854 as the
outstanding amateur. He was a
staff sergeant in the Air Force.
He has travelled extensively as a
good will ambassador for the
State Department and he has
coached in Liberia, Ghana and
Greece.

BIRMINGHAM = Evangelist
Bill Graham spoke to the largest
integrated audience in the history
of the state without incident.


approximately 10000 attended
the mass meeting in Legion Field.


The one day crusade he said
was a great moment. 1t was con-
sidered step forward by Me-
groes and whites.

Mrs. Mile Stephenson, ofLos
Angeles, spent four days in the
city visiting her son and daughter
in law, Mr.. and Mrs. Leonard
Stephens on.


She was the dinner guest on
Easter Sunday of Mr.. and Mrs.
]. K. Plummer.

Your expression of sympathyis
acknowledged and deeply appre-
ciated by Mrs. ]. c. Bruce and
family.

Preparing for track activity Park 10th and E. Jeff
boys pictured the They will ap
the annual Spring Relay Carnival scheduled April 4h and
18th.


neeng) Michael Hman Howard Scott and Raymond
Warner.
Wilson.

the girls track who only cheer

field Whitfield Margaret Whitfield Portia White and
Elenora Whitfield.

birthday party honoring Mrs. Bob ernel Rember CENTER
was held her parents home Saturday night.


Awaiting their piece of cake Leroy Wright Misses Rosie
Sales LYNNE Binfod Mrs. Reber honoreee Mrs. Mae Nc
Carly Roberts Bob Rebe Charles McCary Roma Young
and Oscar Roberts.

Roberts Mesdames Wady Rosie Roberts Leta Michael
